State Key Laboratory of Green Chemical Engineering and Industrial Catalysis, Research Institute of Industrial Catalysis, School of Chemistry & Molecular Engineering, East China University of Science and Technology Shanghai 200237 China The selective oxidation of phenol into cis, cis-muconic acid was carried out with α-zirconium phosphate supported-copper catalysts. It has been found that a sole α-zirconium phosphate exhibited a preferential selectivity (up to 80%) towards dihydroxybenzene (Catechol/Hydroquinone=1.4:1). Moreover, the further studies indicated that α-zirconium phosphate-supported copper catalysts enable to catalyze the oxidative cleavage of catechol into high-added valuable platform molecule cis,cis-muconic acid (ccMA) by in-situ generating performic acid. A 66% conversion of phenol and 60% selectivity towards cis, cis-muconic acid were obtained under mild reaction condition (30 °C, 2 h). The detailed characterization by means of XRD, SEM, TEM, and pyridine-absorbed FT-IR techniques demonstrated that copper(II) species were highly dispersed on α-zirconium phosphate, and could be bonded with the phosphate group of the support. The forming Cu(II)-O-P linkage was proved to be catalytically active species and endowed the supported-copper catalysts with a superior recyclability. The reaction pathway involved hydroxylation of phenol to give a mixture of catechol (CL) and hydroquinone (HQ), followed by the formation of a metal-catechol complex which was then rapidly oxidized into cis, cis-muconic acid (ccMA). In addition, phenol is also present in waste water in chemical industry in terms of high toxicity, carcinogenicity and low biodegradability [1–3]. These effluents could be treated via wet oxidation, which might require pressures and temperatures, and high cost. Moreover, the deep oxidation of phenols yields corresponding quinones including p-benzoquinone (p-BQ) and o-benzoquinone (o-BQ) and also polymers. Consequently, the selective oxidation of phenol to acquire dihydroxybenzene (DHB) including catechol (CL) and hydroquinone (HQ) is of great significance in industry [4–7]. CL and HQ are regarded as prominent substances for applications in photographic film developer, polymerization inhibitors and fine chemicals [1,8,9]. As such, the oxidation of phenol to high-valued chemicals is becoming extremely attractive from environmental perspective. Homogeneous catalysts such as soluble copper salts and iron salts [10,11] have shown great promise in catalytic oxidation of phenol due to the accessible active sites, but harsh reaction conditions and the recovery of catalysts remain a huge challenge. To overcome these drawbacks, heterogeneous catalysts including zeolites [12], metal oxides [13,14], and hydrotalcites [15,16] are used for phenol oxidation reactions. Among these catalysts, molecular zeolites-based [17–19] catalysts have been widely employed for the oxidation of phenol into the mixture of CL and HQ, along with the production of tar in reaction. As a result, there is still a huge challenge to develop highly promising catalysts for the selective oxidation of phenol into CL, HQ and the other high value-added products. The oxidation of phenol normally produces DHB at the first step, including CL and HQ [20,21]. Further oxidation of both CL and HQ might occur in the presence of the oxidants or metal salts, leading to corresponding quinones, other C1-C6 products and tar [22–24]. It is worth noting that the oxidation of catechol could afford o-BQ, which is unstable and can easily be oxidized into muconic acid (MA), maleic acid and oxalic acid, etc. Among these, MA has received much attention as it can be converted further into high-added value chemicals like adipic acid, terephthalic acid, ε-caprolactam and the new monounsaturated monomer 3-hexenedioic acid and 1,4-cyclohex-1/2-enedicarboxylic acid, etc. [25]. Those bulk materials are widely served as precursor of monomers for the production of polymers [26–28]. Cis,cis-muconic acid (ccMA) is one of three isomers of MA, which was first identified in ester form in 1923 via the debromination reaction of 3,4-dibromodiadipate dimethyl ester with pyridine [29]. Nowadays, ccMA is commercially produced by biotechnological pathways. For example, the ortho-cleavage of catechol dioxygenase to ccMA via biological routes has been developed [30]. However, the broth should be kept at a low concentration to avoid toxicity to microorganisms, restricting its large-scale production. As a result, to develop an alternative approach via the catalytic oxidative cracking of catechol has attracted much attention. In previous studies, the oxidative cleavage reaction of catechol with CuCl in pyridine was investigated in the presence of methanol and oxygen, offering monomethyl muconate with 82% yield [31]. However, this method was not environmental-friendly due to the use of large amounts of pyridine and cuprous salt. Afterwards, the oxidation of catechol with peracetic acids as oxidizing agents in the presence/absence of catalysts has been developed, giving about 75% and 70% yield of MA, respectively [32,33]. More recently, it indicated that common iron salts are highly efficient catalysts for the oxidation of catechols with peroxyformic acid as an oxidant, yielding the corresponding substituted muconic acid and muconolactones ranging from 37% to 93% [34]. Nevertheless, the direct oxidation of phenol to ccMA is more advantageous due to easy accessibility of phenol. To the best of our knowledge, fewer reports have been reported for the direct oxidation of phenol to ccMA since this direct oxidation route was extremely challenging. In the pioneering work, the oxidative cleavage of phenol to ccMA was carried out with peroxyacetic acid as the terminal oxidant, giving only ccMA yield of 40% and 24% over iron or copper salt catalysts, respectively [35]. Thereafter, the metal (IV) phosphates have been employed for the oxidative cleavage of phenol into MA, but the yield of MA was very poor (<18%) [36,37]. Moreover, 2,2′-dinitro-4,4′-ditrifluoromethyldiphenyl diselenide can also promote oxidative cleavage of phenol, and MA (mixture of ZE and EE isomer) was obtained with the yield of 50% [38]. Unfortunately, the homogeneous catalyst was subjected to difficult separation and recycling. Therefore, it is highly desirable to develop an efficient, stable, easily recoverable heterogeneous catalysts for the oxidation of phenol into ccMA. Zirconium phosphate (ZrP) is a multifunctional material with excellent physical and chemical properties, which has been applied in fuel cells, electron transfer reactions, and protein surface adsorption [39,40]. Among them, crystalline α-ZrP is extensively employed in catalytic reactions due to its acidity, superior ion exchange capability and easy functionalization [41]. In this aspect, α-ZrP showed high acid catalytic activity for selective conversion of carbohydrates into 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxaldehyde [42] and also Friedel-Crafts alkylation of anisole [43]. In the previous study, we found that ZrP-supported vanadium catalysts exhibited high catalytic activity for the selective oxidation of glycerol into formic acid under the aqueous phase and base-free conditions [44]. Inspired by those results, we intend to design easily accessible, cheap and highly stable ZrP-derived catalysts for catalytic application. In this work, it was found that α-ZrP exhibited high catalytic performance for the oxidation of phenol to DHB with peroxyformic acid as oxidant (CL/HQ=1.4). Notably, α-ZrP-supported copper catalyst enabled to readily cleave phenol into ccMA with peroxyformic acid, affording 66% conversion with 60% selectivity of ccMA under mild conditions (30 °C, 2 h). Moreover, the catalyst can be recycled and exhibited nearly no loss of activity and selectivity of ccMA in consecutive catalytic cycles. The characterization and systematic activity tests indicated that copper(II) sites bound with phosphate of α-ZrP were highly dispersed and played a crucial role in conversion of phenol into ccMA. These catalysts have been characterized in order to show the potential advantages of the supported Cu catalysts and identify the active sites for this selective oxidation reaction. The phase structures of the pristine Cu(OAc)2, α-ZrP and α-ZrP-supported copper catalysts were determined by the XRD patterns. As illustrated in Fig. S1, a neat Cu(OAc)2 displayed a set of well resolved sharp diffraction peaks belonging to the monoclinic structure (JCPDS No. 46–0859). The sole α-ZrP exhibited three main strong diffraction peaks at 11.7°, 19.8° and 24.9°, corresponding to (002), (110) and (112) planes, respectively. These three diffraction planes were in accordance with monoclinic structure with space group P21/n [45]. In addition, it was also found in Fig. S1 that the supported copper catalysts with Cu loadings ranging from 2% to 8% actually showed the same phase structure as that of pristine α-ZrP. Notably, the diffraction peaks from copper species were barely observed in all samples, which may be attributed to the high dispersion of copper species or their crystalline sizes beyond the detection limit of XRD. The FT-IR spectra of α-ZrP and 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 were shown in Fig. S2. It can be seen that a strong peak between 1000 and 1100 cm−1 was assigned to the P-O stretching vibration. The transmission band at 3155 cm−1 corresponded to the P-OH vibration, while the band at 530 cm−1 was due to the (P)-O-H deformation vibration. The band at 1622 cm−1 belonged to the bending vibration of the absorbed water in the sample. In addition, the two sharp transmission bands around 3595 cm−1 and 3510 cm−1 were attributed to the asymmetric and symmetric stretching vibration absorption of water [48]. It can be clearly seen that the introduction of copper weakened the peak at 3155 cm−1 and 530 cm−1, implying that copper species might replace protons of P-OH after the catalyst was subjected to the impregnation and subsequent calcination procedure. The surface morphology of the catalysts revealed by SEM was shown in Fig. S3. Many trenchant plates were clearly visible in pristine α-ZrP, where the discs were deformed with smooth surfaces. Besides, the thin plates of α-ZrP exhibited high crystallinity with identical solid layers placed parallel to each. As can be seen in Fig. S3b, the 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 sample exhibited nearly the same lamellar structure as α-ZrP (Fig. S3a), manifesting that the surface morphology had no significant changes. Next, the HRTEM images of 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 at various magnification was shown in Fig. 1a and b. It turned out that 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 consisted of a few thin nanosheets that were stacked together without any discernible regularity. Besides, P, Zr and Cu were uniformly distributed on the surface of 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 nanosheets, as evidenced by elemental mapping analysis in Fig. 1c. The acidic properties of α-ZrP based catalysts were determined by pyridine-absorbed FT-IR spectroscopy, which was performed in the range of 1700–1400 cm−1 (Fig. S4). Pyridine adsorbed FT-IR spectra of the catalysts showed a band at 1546 cm−1, which was the characteristic bands of the typical pyridinium ion (PyH+), confirming the presence of Brønsted acid sites. Notably, the band of the typical pyridinium ion (PyH+) became much weaker with the increment of copper loading, reflecting that Brønsted acid sites decreased sharply with copper contents. Most interestingly, Brønsted acid sites decreased dramatically and almost vanished due to the introduction of more Cu (8%) into α-ZrP. These results indicated that Cu(II) species could replace the protons of α-ZrP during the preparation of catalysts, indicating that the Cu(II) could be bonded with the phosphate group, forming P-O-Cu(II) linkage, in line with the results revealed in Fig. S2. Further, the band at about 1448 cm−1 was ascribed to the adsorbed pyridine at the Lewis acid site (PyL), while the band at 1491 cm−1 could be attributed to the adsorption of pyridine in both Brønsted and Lewis acid sites [49]. It is noteworthy that the intensity of the Lewis acid sites has increased because extra copper could result in more Lewis acid sites. Furthermore, XPS analysis was applied to determine the element composition and chemical state of copper species in all catalysts as well as Cu(OAc)2. The XPS survey spectra of 4Cu/α-ZrP-m catalysts calcined at different temperatures were shown in Fig. S5, where similar element species of P, Zr, O, and Cu on these catalysts were exhibited. It can be seen that the binding energy of Cu 2p3/2 in Cu(OAc)2 was 934.14 eV ( Fig. 2), and six primary peaks were observed in the XPS spectra of Cu 2p in four catalysts (Fig. 2). For 4Cu/α-ZrP-100 catalyst, peaks located at 932.79 eV could be attributed to the copper hydroxyl acetate [50], while peaks at 935.38 eV was due to Cu(II) species bound to phosphate group of α-ZrP. Notably, the binding energy of the latter peak was higher than that of Cu(OAc)2, indicating the interaction of phosphate in α-ZrP with copper species. For the other catalysts, the Cu 2p3/2 peaks centered in 932.98–933.1 and 935.38–935.92 eV can be assigned to CuO and Cu(II) bonded with phosphate group (Cu(II)-O-P linkage), respectively [51]. The CuO may be produced from the decomposition of Cu(OAc)2 in the course of calcination. The two intensive peaks in the range of 938–946 eV and 960–965 eV presented in the samples were the characteristic satellite peaks of Cu2+. Based on the peak deconvolution analysis, the ratio of Cu(II)-O-P species to the total cationic copper species can be obtained (Table S1). The above results indicate that as the calcination temperature was higher than 200 ºC, the ratio of Cu(II)-O-P species would decrease along with the formation of CuO. 3.2 Phenol oxidation α-ZrP, ZrO2 and SiO2 have been employed as catalysts for selective oxidation of phenol into DHB with in situ generating peroxyformic acid ( Scheme 1). Initially, the mass percentage of peroxyformic acid in solution was determined by the titration method which was given in the supporting information. As shown in Fig. S6a-f, it can be clearly seen that the mass fraction of peroxyformic acid in solution increased with the molar ratio of HCOOH:H2O2 and however it leveled off as the ratio was as high as 5:1 by using 0.5% H3PO4 as catalyst. This can be explained by the reversible process in the generation of peroxyformic acid, the reaction equilibrium may be shifted to the right and in favor of forming peroxyformic acid by raising the molar ratio of HCOOH and H2O2 (Scheme 1). Based on the titration studies, the impacts of various molar ratios of HCOOH:H2O2 on the hydroxylation of phenol using α-ZrP as a catalyst were examined. As shown in Fig. S7a, the reaction cannot occur if sole H2O2 was used as an oxidant, indicating that peroxyformic acid is an actual oxidant. Both phenol conversion and the selectivity to DHB enhanced with the molar ratio of HCOOH:H2O2 but remained unchanged when the ratio was more than 5:1, indicating that the catalytic performance was strongly dependent on the mass fraction of peroxyformic acid as shown in Fig. S6. Meanwhile, p-BQ was also detected as a product owing to the further oxidation of HQ. Next, the effect of the dosage of H2O2 on this reaction was also evaluated (Fig. S7b). It was found that increasing the amount of the oxidant has a beneficial impact on phenol conversion but a detrimental impact on DHB selectivity, which may be caused by over-oxidizing of DHB with excessive H2O2. As a result, the dihydroxylation of phenol can proceed under the optimized conditions of the molar ratio of HCOOH:H2O2 = 5:1 and one equivalent hydrogen peroxide. Next, the phenol oxidation was evaluated with reaction time on the different supports (α-ZrP, ZrO2, and SiO2). As shown in Fig. S8a, the conversion of phenol increased gradually with reaction time in the absence of any catalyst, whereas the selectivity of DHB declined slightly after 2 h due to the deep oxidation of phenol to tar. Comparatively, the inorganic supports like α-ZrP, ZrO2, and SiO2 appeared to show a subtle effect on the catalytic activity (Fig. S8b-d). Interestingly, α-ZrP afforded the highest selectivity towards CL (CL/HQ=1.4) among those catalysts. As can be demonstrated in Fig. S9, the mass fraction of peroxyformic acid increased gradually along with the reaction of HCOOH with H2O2. Obviously, α-ZrP indeed facilitated the formation of peroxyformic acid under the identical conditions, which was more favorable for the production of DHB. Actually, it has been reported that H2O2 penetrates into the interlayers in α-ZrP and in-situ forming peroxyformic acid is thereby stabilized by phosphate group via hydrogen bonding, which facilitated the oxygen transfer reaction [36,37]. As a result, α-ZrP can be used as a superior support to immobilize copper species for the further oxidative cleavage of phenol. Based on the aforementioned results, the α-ZrP-supported copper catalysts were subsequently assessed for the oxidation of phenol with peroxyformic acid as an oxidant. The high ratio of H2O2 to phenol (4:1) was adopted in order to form ccMA. As displayed in Table 1, DHB and p-BQ were only detected, but no ccMA was formed without catalysts or with α-ZrP catalyst (entries 1 and 2), and moreover, α-ZrP afforded marginally higher activity than that without catalyst, likely owing to the more generation of peroxyformic acid in-situ (Fig. S9). However, the sole α-ZrP actually afforded much lower selectivity to CL and HQ due to the over-oxidation of DHB at the high ratio of H2O2/Phenol (entry 2), compared to that in Fig. S8b (H2O2/Phenol =1:1). Besides, Cu(OAc)2 and monovalent copper salts CuOAc was capable to oxidize phenol into ccMA in spite of relatively low selectivity to ccMA (entries 3 and 4), indicating that Cu(I) and Cu(II) species were active for the oxidative cleavage of phenol. However, both of them are dissolvable in the reaction mixture, making the recovery of Cu salts and the product purification very difficult. Notably, α-ZrP supported-copper catalyst 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 showed a superior catalytic activity, with 66% conversion and 60% selectivity to ccMA (entry 5). Additionally, 4Cu/am-ZrP-200 also exhibited similar conversion and ccMA selectivity with that of 4Cu/α-ZrP-200, indicating that the crystalline phases of ZrP seemed not to offer a significant effect on catalytic performance (entry 6). Especially, the reaction was also carried out under nitrogen atmosphere, and no obvious changes were observed (entry 5 vs 7), which demonstrated that the peroxyformic acid was an actual oxidant rather than molecule oxygen in air. Additionally, if the reaction time was prolonged to 24 h, the conversion increased significantly but the yield of ccMA slightly declined (entry 8), indicating that side-reaction occurred for long reaction time. It was noted that the product ccMA can be easily isolated by recrystallization as a pale-yellow powder and its purity (98%) was further proved by 1H NMR, 13C NMR and MS (Fig. S10 and S11). Based on the results above, phenol (10 g) was oxidized on a large-scale. It can be found that 5.9 g ccMA (Yield=39%) was obtained as shown in Fig. S10 (upper, inserted), confirming that this approach is feasible for phenol oxidation reaction on a large scale. Next, the reaction conditions of the oxidative cleavage of phenol were optimized by screening reaction parameters. As shown in Fig. 3a, when the molar ratio of HCOOH:H2O2 was below 2:1, the amounts of peroxyformic acid were insufficient to completely convert CL to ccMA, leading to a residual CL in the reaction mixture. Both the conversion of phenol and ccMA selectivity showed a continuous increase with the ratio of HCOOH:H2O2. However, the selectivity of ccMA decreased slightly as the ratio was more than 5:1, accompanying with the increasing generation of HQ and p-BQ as main side-products. From Fig. 3b, conversion of phenol increased with the dosage of H2O2, but an excessive H2O2 (more than 4 equivalents of H2O2) led to a lower selectivity of ccMA due to the over-oxidation reaction. Besides, as shown in Fig. 3c, with the increment of the reaction temperature from 20 °C to 60 °C, the phenol conversion increased from 41% to 80%, followed by dropping to 72%. Meantime, the selectivity to ccMA reached the optimum at 30 °C but decreased sharply thereafter. Especially, no ccMA was detected at elevated temperature to 60 °C due to rapid decomposition of peroxyformic acid. It can be seen from Fig. 3d that the oxidation reaction of phenol actually happened quite quickly and afforded 66% conversion and 60% ccMA selectivity within 2 h. As the reaction time was further prolonged (>2 h), the conversion of phenol increased slowly but the selectivity of ccMA declined (Fig. 3d), which was probably due to the formation of polymer and tar resulting from over-oxidation and condensation. Overall, the oxidative cleavage of phenol into ccMA was strongly dependent on the percentage of peroxyformic acid as revealed in Fig. S6. Although the oxidation reaction rate is normally enhanced with the reaction temperature, high temperatures might result in a side-reaction and also a fast decomposition of peroxyformic acid, which is unfavorable for the production of ccMA. Furthermore, the impact of the catalyst supports on catalytic activity and selectivity was investigated and shown in Fig. 4a. It was found that 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 exhibited marginally the highest ccMA yield among these catalysts. The other anchoring copper catalysts actually produced no discernible difference in terms of phenol conversion or ccMA yield. The effect of copper loading on the oxidation reaction was also investigated (Fig. 4b). The conversion of phenol enhanced gradually with copper contents but kept almost unchanged as the loading of Cu was higher than 4%. Besides, the ccMA selectivity had no obvious changes when copper contents ranged from 2% to 10%. Next, it was found that the catalyst calcined at 200 °C can give the optimal ccMA selectivity (60%) (Fig. 4c). As reflected by XPS, copper species existed in the form of CuO and Cu-O-P on α-ZrP surface. Since CuO actually gave poor ccMA selectivity as compared to Cu species in “ion status” (Table 1, entry 9 vs entries 3 and 4). As a result, Cu(II) species bound with phosphate groups were actually active species. However, the contents of CuO increased with calcination temperature (Table S1), which may have a negative impact on the selectivity of ccMA (Fig. 4c). As a consequence, 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 catalyst demonstrated the highest catalytic performance among these catalysts, which resulted from not only the accumulation of peroxyformic acid on the layered structure of α-ZrP (Fig. S9), but also the formation of catalytically active Cu(II)-O-P species. As shown in Fig. 4d, the effect of acidic additives on the reaction was also examined as well. The conversion of phenol displayed no significant changes with different additives. In the absence of acidic additives, 59% conversion and 51% ccMA selectivity were achieved. The selectivity of ccMA increased slightly if H2SO4 and HNO3 were added. Especially, phosphoric acid as an acidic additive gave the highest selectivity for ccMA, resulting from its catalytic role for the formation of peroxyacid and effective stabilization for peroxyacid species [52]. Notably, when hydrochloric acid was added, the additional by-products including o- and m-chlorophenol are produced. 3.3 Catalyst recycling The reusability of the catalyst is one of the most important parameters in terms of further application and economic feasibility. Accordingly, the recyclability of the 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 catalyst was evaluated under optimal reaction conditions. After each run, the catalyst was separated by simple centrifugation, and the residue adhering to the catalyst was washed with ethanol and dried before putting into the next run. As presented in Fig. 5a, the selectivity of ccMA remained almost constant over four recycling experiments, but dropped slightly from 60% to 50% at the fifth run. ICP results indicated that the copper content on catalyst decreased only from 4.0% to 3.2% after five cycles, which revealed that α-ZrP could hamper Cu species from leaching effectively. According to the SEM characterization, the laminate structure of the used 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 catalyst was well retained (Fig. S12a), proving the superior stability of α-ZrP. In addition, the spent 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 catalyst displayed the same XRD pattern as the new one (Fig. S1 and S12b), which further suggested that α-ZrP was stable and did not undergo phase transformation. Notably, it was found that the ratio of CuO derived from Cu 2p spectrum increased in the spent 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 in comparison with the fresh one (Fig. S12c and Fig. 2), which may account for the slight decline of ccMA selectivity in the consecutive runs. Overall, the good recyclability of the present copper-supported catalyst mainly resulted from the strong coordination of Cu(II) with the phosphate group on the surface of α-ZrP. For comparison, the recyclability of 4Cu/SiO2-200 and 4Cu/ZrO2-200 were also evaluated (Fig. 5b). In contrast to 4Cu/α-ZrP-200, after the two catalysts afore-mentioned were recycled only once, both the catalytic activity and selectivity of ccMA dropped sharply due to the obvious leaching of copper in these catalysts. ICP analysis indicated that only after two cycles the Cu contents on 4Cu/SiO2-200 and 4Cu/ZrO2-200 catalysts were declined to 0.04 wt% and 0.2 wt% respectively, demonstrating that the copper leaching was extremely serious in the two catalysts. The XPS spectra of 4Cu/SiO2-200 and 4Cu/ZrO2-200 was presented in Fig. S13, and two main peaks can be observed around 933 and 953 eV, accompanied by two shake-up satellite peaks at 934 and 963 eV, indicating the existence of Cu2+. Moreover, the asymmetric region of Cu 2p3/2 could be deconvoluted into two symmetric peaks, which could be ascribed to CuO (932.8–933.1 eV) and Cu(II) species (934.5–934.9 eV) with the interaction with the supports due to charge transfer from Cu2+ toward the supports [53]. However, as shown in Fig. 2, the binding energy of the Cu(II) 2p3/2 on 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 catalyst was much higher in comparison with that of 4Cu/SiO2–200 and 4Cu/ZrO2–200 catalysts, revealing that charge transfer from Cu2+ toward the α-ZrP was more significant. On the basis of these results, it was indicated that there was a stronger electronic interaction between Cu2+ species and α-ZrP, which can endow α-ZrP-supported copper catalyst with superior stability. Furthermore, it was obviously observed that CuO species were dominant on the 4Cu/SiO2-200 and 4Cu/ZrO2-200 catalysts as compared with 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 catalyst (Fig. S13 and Fig. 2), indicating that the CuO species tend to leach more easily than the bound Cu(II) species. The above results confirmed that the Cu(II)-O-P species on 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 catalyst played a vital role in improving recyclability. 3.4 Reaction pathway As mentioned above, the oxidation of phenol proceeded by the following steps: the phenol was initially converted into DHB (CL and HQ) over α-ZrP, and then the aromatic ring (such as CL) was subjected to the oxidative cleavage into ccMA with the Cu(II)-O-P sites on α-ZrP. The oxidation of phenol to DHB is generally through a free radical process in the literature [54–56]. To gain an insight into the reaction pathway, radical inhibition experiments with 1 equivalent of 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol (BHT) were performed. The specific procedure was as follows. After the reaction was carried out for 10 min, BHT was added and the mixture was continued to react for some time. As shown in Fig. S14, either the phenol hydroxylation or oxidative cleavage of phenol remained almost unchanged with duration time, indicating that the reaction might occur catalytically rather than via the free-radical pathway. Phenol oxidation by “ion mechanism” has been reported to afford DHB and then CL was cleaved oxidatively to ccMA via forming the metal-catechol complex [32,35–37,57]. In our work, it was found that the metal center is crucial for ccMA production from the oxidative cleavage of phenol, as phenol cannot be oxidized to ccMA in the absence of Cu sites (Table 1, entries 1 and 2). Besides, if sole CL was also employed as substrate, a trace of ccMA was obtained in the absence of catalyst or with α-ZrP as a catalyst ( Scheme 2, Eqs. 1 and 2). However, the excellent yield of ccMA (80%) was achieved with 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 as catalyst (Scheme 2, Eq. 3), reflecting that CL might be the reaction intermediate and the copper species were indispensable in the direct oxidation of phenol into ccMA. According to these findings, it was speculated that the oxidation of phenol underwent the following steps as shown in Scheme 3: (1) Phenol was initially oxidized to DHB (CL and HQ) with peroxyformic acid as a terminal oxidant, and α-ZrP had a positive influence on the production of DHB. However, α-ZrP is not active in the oxidative cleavage of CL; (2) The CL might act as an intermediate and will form Cu(II)-catechol-complex; (3) The subsequent formation of the corresponding o-benzoquinone complex resulted from electron transfer from the CL (catechol-complex) via metal to coordinated peroxyformic acid molecules, leading to the reduction of peroxyformic acid into formic acids. In the meantime, the labile o-benzoquinone complex was subjected to further oxidative cleavage to give ccMA. Overall, the forming Cu(II)-O-P species on the surface played a pivotal role in the oxidative cleavage of phenol into ccMA. 4 Conclusion In this work, we have demonstrated that α-ZrP showed a preferential selectivity towards CL (CL/HQ=1.4) in the catalytic oxidation of phenol due to its laminate structure. Furthermore, it was found that α-ZrP supported copper catalysts showed high catalytic performance for the further oxidative cleavage of CL. The as-prepared 4Cu/α-ZrP-200 catalyst exhibited high phenol conversion (66%) and ccMA selectivity (60%). The characterization indicated that α-ZrP supported Cu(II) catalyst remained highly stable and exhibited a superior reusability owing to the strong interaction of phosphate group on α-ZrP with copper species. Especially, the forming Cu(II)-O-P species were crucial for catalyzing cleavage reaction of CL into ccMA. Overall, this work provided a promising approach towards the synthesis of high-added chemicals by optimizing the electronic and coordination properties of the support with Cu (II) species. coredata.dc:description: The selective oxidation of phenol into cis, cis-muconic acid was carried out with α-zirconium phosphate supported-copper catalysts. It has been found that a sole α-zirconium phosphate exhibited a preferential selectivity (up to 80%) towards dihydroxybenzene (Catechol/Hydroquinone=1.4:1). Moreover, the further studies indicated that α-zirconium phosphate-supported copper catalysts enable to catalyze the oxidative cleavage of catechol into high-added valuable platform molecule cis,cis-muconic acid (ccMA) by in-situ generating performic acid. A 66% conversion of phenol and 60% selectivity towards cis, cis-muconic acid were obtained under mild reaction condition (30 °C, 2 h). The detailed characterization by means of XRD, SEM, TEM, and pyridine-absorbed FT-IR techniques demonstrated that copper(II) species were highly dispersed on α-zirconium phosphate, and could be bonded with the phosphate group of the support. The forming Cu(II)-O-P linkage was proved to be catalytically active species and endowed the supported-copper catalysts with a superior recyclability. The reaction pathway involved hydroxylation of phenol to give a mixture of catechol (CL) and hydroquinone (HQ), followed by the formation of a metal-catechol complex which was then rapidly oxidized into cis, cis-muconic acid (ccMA).
coredata.dc:title: Zirconium phosphate supported copper catalyst for selective oxidation of phenol to cis, cis-muconic acid
